metadata.name: Access To Windows DPAPI Master Keys By Uncommon Applications
metadata.comment: Detects file access requests to the the Windows Data Protection API Master keys by an uncommon application. This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::masterkey" function

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM file_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (activity_id = 2 AND (contains(lower(file.name), lower('\\\\microsoft\\\\protect\\\\s-1-5-18\\\\')) OR contains(lower(file.name), lower('\\\\microsoft\\\\protect\\\\s-1-5-21-'))) AND NOT (startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\program files\\\\')) OR startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\program files (x86)\\\\')) OR startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\windows\\\\system32\\\\')) OR startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\windows\\\\syswow64\\\\'))))

output.summary: Detects file access requests to the the Windows Data Protection API Master keys by an uncommon application. This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::masterkey" function
